text: [Music]
with us I don't think we most military
don't look at it that way we don't
calculate uh that I might not come home
that's that's like a factor that's never
calculated into our decision-making
process our biggest thing is we might
let the guy down next to us so for us
it's our our
training um to kind of go over there and
execute our mission that's our biggest
thing and the Marine Corp pushes that
mission accomplishment Mission
accomplishment you know then troop
welfare and I think with that mindset we
go in we're already pretty prepared for
what's going to go on you know for for
me engaging the enemy or anything I
always kind of thought I was doing what
I was training to do and I kind of
separated emotion from it and and I've
gotten better at it over the years every
deployment I went back I understood that
emotion is only weakness over here for
me I I must think objectively I don't uh
General Mattis always says phrase no
better friend no worst enemy and I think
it's like the best thing cuz really it's
it kind of explains what the fighting
man has to kind of do over there but
it's very hard it's hard to go over
there without emotion it's you know
after one of your friends gets hit by a
roadside bomb it's hard not to be pissed
but the truth is you got to realize hey
this is the nature of the Beast I got to
drive on I'm not going to take it out on
other Iraqis that aren't involved you
know um I got hit by a a rocket PR
grenade in uh April 7th 2004 and that
initial push into
fuia um for me we we got slammed going
into an ambush and uh we were the point
vehicle it actually blew off my
assistant team leader both his hands
Eddie Wright um it broke my arm blew off
my trigger finger and it uh it wounded
everyone else in my vehicle uh what we
did we pushed out of the Kill Zone and
actually got stuck in the secondary Kill
Zone uh where we were surrounded by
about uh 26 guys and uh we had to do
Medical Aid to ourselves but I put a
tourniquet on and uh one of my young
Lance cor Lance cor Maison actually
tated um up Eddie but uh for us it was
actually kind of funny because this is
it's like that Marine cor humor that you
see see throughout the series Eddie
writes in the backseat cracking jokes
and the guy has no hands and uh for me
it's like C breeds Cal so I'm like
if this guy's laughing about this you
know how can I be worried I'm definitely
not as bad as he is and he actually made
a bad situation kind of somewhat
entertaining and then we just went back
and we just executed what we trained for
cuz in in high high levels of stress you
always Resort back to your last highest
level of training for me this is my
third combat tour so it wasn't like I
was worried I just I just kind of
everything was muscle memory I did what
we had to do to survive it we got back
out of the Kill Zone and uh probably
about an hour and a half two hours later
we were medevaced out of
there I always kind of promised that I
was gonna I was going to make things
right for Eddie I was kind of you know
after seeing him in the hospital
actually brought me to tear to seeing
him in ICU
it's hard I you know it's hard to say I
don't want to just say I want to go kill
a bunch of people to get back you know
Revenge because you know then again
that's kind of you know using my emotion
part but I wanted I wanted to make it
feel like that we were wounded that day
for something you know it wasn't for
nothing I wanted to get back there and
and try and fix the problems Iraq had
and if that meant fight it meant fight
if that meant fix the infrastructure or
work with the local Iraq he do whatever
I can whatever's in my power to make
that place better and and I learned a
lot cuz my fourth and fifth tours were
totally different than what you see in
generation kill um a lot of what I did
is actually live with the Iraqis um you
the 24 man platoon and we we created
kind of an atmosphere where they could
be safe where they're around we learned
off them we learned everything from how
to cook uh their their flatbread their
hobus to how to hook up Italian porn on
their TVs to teaching them how to patrol
um you know and working with these
people closely and try to get rid of
everything from the criminal analy
that's that's like running loose in Iraq
to work with the terrorists and uh the
other elements that are there because
it's very complex and I learned so much
more of my my fourth and fifth tour than
than I could ever imagine I mean I kind
of look back at my my first multiple
tours and it's like wow if I knew what I
knew now you know we could have done
such a better job back
then we did it on this place called pork
chop island is like uh I think in the
history of the world I don't think
anyone's been injured on that island but
uh for me it's like getting back on the
horse and I was actually paranoid I
actually kind of had it must be what
Captain America felt in of1 I was very
paranoid because I was calculating in
every every combat I've seen in the past
like possible ambushes that can go down
and everything and my mind was just
racing and uh and I was like man why why
did I come back here and um I think
after I got over there it was just like
one day of extreme paranoia for some
reason but uh after that I went back to
just pushing emotion to the side and
doing my job and I had no problem
